title: 104_hr2439
content: The "State Infrastructure Banks Act of 1995" allows states to use infrastructure banks for financing transportation projects, providing more flexibility in developing public-private partnerships. Congress recognizes the need for new financial concepts in transportation programs that traditional federal reimbursement programs cannot accommodate. The "State Infrastructure Banks Act of 1995" defines key terms such as Secretary, State, and State infrastructure bank. State infrastructure banks are created to finance transportation projects at the state or multi-state level. Congress grants consent to States to establish State infrastructure banks and enter into interstate compacts to promote regional investment in transportation infrastructure. State infrastructure banks can provide loans, issue debt, and offer assistance to entities constructing transportation projects. State infrastructure banks can provide loans, issue debt, and offer assistance to public or private entities for transportation projects eligible for financial assistance under specific laws. The assistance can cover part or all of the construction or capital costs. State infrastructure banks, established under the Intermodal Surface Transportation Efficiency Act of 1991, can provide loans or assistance to public or private entities for transportation projects. The assistance may cover the construction or capital costs of a qualifying project and can be subordinated to other debt financing. "Other assistance" includes funds for credit enhancements or as a capital reserve for bond financing. To qualify as a State infrastructure bank, each participating State must meet specific requirements. This includes ensuring that any assistance provided is subordinated to other debt financing for the project. "Other assistance" encompasses various forms of financial support such as credit enhancements, capital reserves for bond financing, issuance costs, insurance, interest rate subsidies, and other approved leveraging tools. To qualify as a State infrastructure bank, participating States must maintain an investment grade rating on debt issuances or have sufficient insurance. Investment income generated by deposited funds must be credited to the bank for providing loans and other financing. The State infrastructure bank must maintain viability and ensure investment income from deposited funds is credited to the bank, available for loans to transportation projects, and invested in Treasury securities or other financing instruments to enhance project leveraging. The State infrastructure bank must ensure that loan repayments can be credited back to the bank for any purpose, and loans will bear appropriate interest to make projects feasible. The State infrastructure bank must ensure that loaned funds are available with positive interest, repayment starts within 5 years of project completion, repayment term not exceeding 30 years, and limit loan amount to what the State transfers. The State infrastructure bank must ensure loan repayment starts within 5 years of project completion, with a maximum term of 30 years. The bank's annual report to the Secretary is due by September 30 each year. The Secretary must ensure Federal disbursements for capital reserves align with historic rates for the Federal-aid highway program. In administering the Act, the Secretary must ensure Federal disbursements for capital reserves align with historic rates for the Federal-aid highway program and specify procedures for State infrastructure bank operations. States can transfer up to 15% of Title 23 apportionments to the bank. States can transfer up to 15% of Federal funds apportioned under Title 23 to a State infrastructure bank, with disbursements not exceeding the traditional rate of the Federal-aid highway program. A State may transfer funds suballocated under Title 23 to a State infrastructure bank, with disbursements not exceeding the traditional rate of the Federal-aid highway program. The deposit of Federal apportionments into a State infrastructure bank does not create any obligation on the part of the United States to third parties. The State infrastructure bank does not create any obligation on the part of the United States to third parties. Any security or debt financing instrument issued by a State infrastructure bank must explicitly state that it does not constitute a commitment, guarantee, or obligation of the United States. Sections 3335 and 6503 of title 31, United States Code, do not apply to funds used as a capital reserve under this Act. Additionally, a State may contribute an amount not exceeding 2% of the fiscal year's budget to a State infrastructure bank. Management of Federal Funds: Sections 3335 and 6503 of title 31, United States Code, do not apply to funds used as a capital reserve under this Act. Program Administration: A State may contribute up to 2% of Federal funds deposited into the State infrastructure bank for administering the bank.
